vectorData.altText:
P1 = pneumocyte
BM = fused basement membraneE = endothelial cell
Er = erythrocyte (RBC)
thinness of the epithelia promotes rapid and usually passive molecular transport; e.g. alveoli, endothelium, mesothelia

Pleural, pericardial and peritoneal cavities are lined by mesothelia.
Mesothelia, combined with its underlying connective tissue, forms serous membranes (pleura, pericardium, peritoneum) that secrete serous fluid into the body cavity.
Serous fluid (pleural fluid, pericardial fluid, peritoneal fluid) acts as a lubricant that facilitates the movement of the organs within the body cavity.

line surfaces involved in the more active processes of secretion and absorption; the subcellular organelles required to support these processes necessitates the larger cell volume

may have microvilli, which increase the surface area of the apical membrane and therefore the rate of molecular transport. You learned about  microvilli on a previous slide; if you’d like to review it, click here:

e.g. some ducts, such as in the kidney; in the image, the double-headed arrows illustrate that some ions and molecules are secreted into the forming urine to be eliminated, while others are absorbed back into the body and therefore conserved.

 surface area of epithelia that function in absorption     , secretion
minimally-motile, finger-like extensions of apical surface
core: actin microfilaments cross-linked to each other, to the membrane, and to the terminal web
number of microvilli on the apical cell surface is proportional to the rate at which molecules move through the apical cell membrane
short, sparse microvilli in tissues involved in low rates of molecular transfer
tall, densely-packed microvilli in tissues involved in high rates of molecular transfer
especially well-developed in the small intestine and kidney.
the process by which molecules are moved INTO the body
the process by which molecules are moved OUT OF the body
Specializations of the Apical Surface I: Microvilli
line surfaces involved in high rates of secretion and absorption, e.g. small intestine      where it has microvilli and goblet cells and the gall bladder      , where it has microvilli.

breakdown of food into its nutrient components occurs within the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract
the small intestine is responsible for the absorption of nutrients from its lumen, across the apical aspect of its epithelial lining into the epithelial cell cytoplasm, and from there into the underlying CT
here, nutrients are picked up by blood vessels (BV) for distribution elsewhere in the body
this process is facilitated by the densely-packed microvilli that greatly increase the surface area of the apical membrane, and therefore the rate of nutrient absorption.

The gall bladder functions to store and concentrate bile, a secretion of the liver that functions in the digestion of lipids in the small intestine.
It is lined by a simple columnar epithelia with microvilli.
To concentrate bile, it actively transports water out of its lumen, into the underlying CT, where it is carried away by blood vessels. Molecular transport is facilitated by the increased surface area imparted by the microvilli, and paracellular movement of molecules is prevented by the tight junctions between the columnar epithelial cells.
Simple Columnar Epithelia of the Gall Bladder

gives the appearance of being stratified, but all cells contact the basement membrane, so it is a simple epithelium
is usually ciliated, esp. in respiratory tract, where it works with goblet cells to clean inspired air before it is exposed to the gas exchange surfaces of the lung; review cilia here:
pseudo = false; giving the appearance of something it’s not; for example the pseudoGucci purse I bought for $17 at Value Village
Specializations of the Apical Surface II: Cilia

found on epithelia specialized to move fluid along their luminal surface 
highly motile, synchronized, finger-like extensions of apical cell membrane
core: microtubules with associated proteins, inc. dynein 
taller than microvilli
very well developed in respiratory epithelia and uterine tubes

respiratory epithelium lines the airways that conduct air to the gas-exchange surfaces of the lungs
goblet cells (GC), displaying short, blunt microvilli, produce mucous, which coats the surface
particulate matter in inspired air (e.g. dust) sticks to the mucous coating the surfaces; this cleans the air
cilia on ciliated cells (CC) beat synchronously toward the pharynx; the mucous and dust is swallowed, eliminating the dust

lines internal surfaces requiring protection from abrasion, pathogens, chemical attack
must be kept moist by glandular secretion
locations are logical, given its function in protection of underlying tissues; e.g. lining of mouth, throat, esophagus, rectum, anus, vagina, cervix

Light micrograph showing stratified squamous nonkeratinized epithelium lining the cervix.
Epidermal cells here are joined by desmosomes, which helps this epithelia to withstand abrasive forces. Review desmosomes here: 
Notice that the cells adjacent to the basement membrane do not appear squamous, but the surface cells do; remember, epithelia are named according the shape of the cells adjacent to the lumen

do NOT form belts; they are arranged more like rivets or spot-welds, here and there, joining the lateral surfaces of the cells
Desmosomes link the intermediate filament network of the cytoskeleton of adjacent cells;esp. well developed in the skin
like ZA, the transmembrane proteins that link across the intercellular space are cadherins
present throughout an epithelial sheet; effectively linking the intermediate filament network of all cells, thus distributing shear forces throughout the entire sheet
the more there are, the more strongly the cells are bound together
Anchoring Cells to Each Other: Desmosomes

Light micrograph showing stratified squamous keratinized epithelium from the palm of the hand, for instance.

Cells of this epithelium undergo keratinization, a process which converts its surface into a sheet of dead, protein-packed cells that maintain their strong connection to each other via desmosomes, and develop water-resistant properties and thus protect the surface of our bodies from physical forces and dehydration.

line external surfaces requiring protection from abrasion, pathogens, chemical attack
in addition, protects against dehydration
epidermal layer of the skin; it functions to prevent loss of body fluid by dehydration across the body surface; burn victims may succumb to their injuries because fluid cannot be transfused fast enough to offset the loss of fluid that occurs across the body surface once the epidermis is destroyed

a stratified epithelium that lines surfaces which must allow stretch & recoil, such as the urinary bladder and ureter
surface cells are domed in shape, when the organ is empty and the epithelium is therefore not under tension.
cells flatten, epithelium appears to consist of fewer layers, as the organ fills and the epithelium must stretch
